speaker.bio:
Richard has been programming since age 4, and had his first game-publishing contract at age 14 (though to his knowledge, the publisher never actually sold a single copy). He has worked both on AAA games at studios such as Rebellion and on shoestring-budget indie games. Many people know him from assorted forums and chat rooms, where he has helped thousands of developers solve problems in their projects.

He has worked at Unity since late 2014, where he is involved in projects across the company, with a particular interest in problems around quality, data, philosophy, and usability. In his spare time, he composes music and experiments with food.

sessions.title: The Future of Connected Games: Unity and the Cloud

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: From connected single-player to real-time multiplayer, are you ready to explore the spectrum of connected games? Join Google Cloud Platform and Unity product managers Micah Baker and Brandi House to discover how you can use Google and Unity to build and scale games that serve a global audience.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: For many years, it's been Brandi's passion to make games that connect people in exciting and creative ways. From Bungie to Funomena, she has explored a breadth of games development ranging from AAA to indie. Now Oculus to Unity, she's focused on the technology required to democratize Connected Games, so more developers can bring the online games they dream of to life.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: As the product manager leading the strategy for gaming on the Google Cloud Platform, Micah is committed to enabling developers to realize their vision for great games. An avid gamer on all major platforms, he never hesitates to get involved in games that were built with a passion for immersive storytelling, innovative multiplayer experiences and breathtaking artwork.

sessions.title: The Next Frontier in Ad Innovation for Mobile

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Join industry and Unity experts as they discuss the latest and greatest formats, including highly engaging augmented reality (AR) ads. In this enlightening session, you'll learn how these innovative ad formats are changing the way both brands and games connect with their audiences and achieve desired campaign results.

speaker.title: Senior Product Marketing Manager, Monetization
speaker.bio: Tracy is a Senior Product Marketer at Unity, working across adaptive gaming and mobile business products. She focuses on innovative product solutions for both brand advertisers and game developers.

speaker.title: VP of Experiential Technology
speaker.bio: As VP of Experiential Technology at Digitas, Keith specializes in the technologies that power innovative marketing and advertising campaigns for our clients.  He has worked with iconic brands like Whirlpool, AMEX, MIllerCoors, Disney and PlayStation to develop the next generation of digital creative technology experiences.  With a background in Production and CGI, Keith specializes in immersive technologies like AR & VR.  Meanwhile, in the Lab, Keith leads a steady stream of research and development, prototyping and experimentation to find the next innovative solution for Digitas’ client partners.

speaker.title: Product Manager, Unity Ads
speaker.bio: A lifelong avid gamer, Juho is passionate about helping developers succeed. At Unity, he aims to do so via his work on Advertiser Services. He focuses on making user acquisition simple and effective with new tools and machine learning algorithms. In his free time, he's an RPG and strategy games player.

sessions.title: To be revealed
To be revealed
To be revealed
To be revealed: Unity + Animation Partner
Troubleshooting Memory-Related Issues with the Memory Profiler

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Finding leaking memory, the biggest memory allocations, or just poking around to see what was happening on the memory level has not always been easy, but is essential to getting the best performance for your game. Come to this session to learn how the Memory Profiler improves upon Unity's past tools and helps you troubleshoot memory issues faster.

speaker.title: Programmer
speaker.bio: Even in his early days, Greg knew that he wanted to create computer games. He started realizing his dream around 2000, when he joined his first non-profit indie group. Around the same time, he decided that what he really loves about game development is not creating games themselves but creating technology that allows others to build games they dream about. This discovery pushed him down a long and difficult path of engine development. Multiple indie and AAA game projects later, he is still passionate about his work. Since 2017, he has worked in Unity's Copenhagen office, where he focuses on C++ containers, low-level memory management, and tools to investigate memory issues.

speaker.title: Developer
speaker.bio: Stephanie is a dedicated developer who spends most of her time thinking about the future of game development. She thrives on building the next generation of technologies that will both democratize development and improve efficiency for all game developers. Over the years, she has worked in both R&D and game production on many titles in the industry as well as on her own indie game and engine project. All of which provide her with a well-rounded vision of what the future development process will require. She joined Unity in 2017 as part of the Core team and has been focusing on the new Memory Profiler tool.

sessions.title: Unity 2019 R&D Roadmap

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Our VP of Product, Andrew Bowell, and Product Manager, Stine Kjærbye, will take you through our roadmap for future features and enhancements in our upcoming 2018.3 release and in the upcoming 2019 cycle. Get up to speed on the latest developments in ECS, the improved prefabs workflows, terrain editor, VFX editor, connected games, and much more. You'll learn when you can expect new features and functionality to be released and also have the opportunity to ask questions.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: When Stine joined Unity in 2013, she was the only designer in R&D. Soon after, she was leading Unity's first UX team and later transitioned to product management, where she works closely with the core R&D team bringing a user-centered approach to software development. Stine believes it doesn't matter how advanced a technology is, if it doesn't truly serve people.

speaker.title: VP Product
speaker.bio: Andrew heads up Product for Unity R&D. Together with the incredible engineers in R&D and Unity's awesome user base, Andrew's team helps to set the direction for Unity's technology from Features to Platforms, Graphics to Core all connected to Unity's ever more powerful Developer Services. Andrew graduated from a youth of C64 and x86 fiddling and stepped foot for real into the games industry in 2000. At Havok Andrew was part of the team that got Havok Physics off the ground going on to power games like Skyrim, Halo, Assassin's Creed and Uncharted.

sessions.title: Unity for Film: Product Roadmap and Q&A

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: If you are or will be using Unity for film, you won't want to miss this in-depth talk from Sr. Technical Product Manager for Film, Mathieu Muller. Starting with an overview of upcoming features, enhancements, packages, templates and integrations, he'll also cover the different types of solutions Unity offers for film and animation, and finish up with a Q&A for all your burning technical questions.

speaker.title: Sr. Technical Product Manager, Film
speaker.bio: Mathieu was born between Atari2600 and Commodore64, and studied in France, Switzerland and Canada. He  worked for 13 years as a software engineer on a graphics engine for professional flight simulators and on games middleware. At Unity for four years, he travels around the world as a field engineer, visiting film and game studios.

sessions.title: Unlock Your CAD Data for Real-Time Development (Unity+PiXYZ) – AEC

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: This advanced presentation will focus on the exciting uses for high-resolution BIM data and provide an in-depth look at importing into Unity with a PiXYZ plugin for AEC (architecture, engineering, and construction) projects. We'll demonstrate how the Revit format and Rule Engine will be performed by Unity while using PiXYZ to simplify the models for developers. We'll be showing you previews of the upcoming photorealistic Unity material library specifically built for the AEC market.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: Luc is from Montreal, Canada. Working in the movie and architectural industries for over 13 years, he has contributed to the fields of photorealistic rendering, FBX format, virtual movie sets, Unity Services and 3D content-creation tools.

sessions.title: Virtual Cinematography & Hollywood: The Tools Powering Ready Player One and Blade Runner 2049

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: When two veterans of the film and game industries, Wes Potter and Habib Zargarpour, joined forces to create a virtual cinematography company, they were trying to fill a void in production because directors and DPs were becoming increasingly removed from their work on CG productions. The result was Vancouver-based Digital Monarch Media (DMM), where traditional filmmaking ideologies meet real-time game-engine technology via their Virtual Film Tools suite. Their goal was to bring the creative process back into the shots on set, as if it was all practical shooting. Don't miss this live demonstration of the innovative tools used by the likes of Steven Spielberg and Denis Villeneuve!

speaker.title: CCO
speaker.bio: Habib has over 14 years of experience in visual effects for film and 14 years in the games industry. Nominated for two Academy Awards and the winner of two BAFTAs in visual effects, his recent role as Visual Effects Consultant on Blade Runner 2049, partnering with VFX Supervisor John Nelson, allowed him to make full use of his creative and visual skills on a broad scope of work. In 2016, he worked with VFX Supervisor Scott Anderson on A Series of Unfortunate Events for Netflix. Prior to that, he was Partner Director of Visuals at Microsoft Studios, responsible for visuals across all publishing titles for Xbox One, Windows, and HoloLens. Some of his other film projects include Twister, The Perfect Storm, two Star Trek films, Star Wars: Episode I, The Bourne Identity, Spawn, and Signs. Habib received a Visual Effects Society (VES) award in 2006 for Need for Speed: Most Wanted. His project RYSE: Son of Rome was a launch title for Xbox One and is still recognized as a visual showcase for the platform. He developed a real-time visualization system used by Jon Favreau and DP Bill Pope to film The Jungle Book and by Steven Spielberg on Ready Player One. Habib is also an active member of AMPAS VFX Branch, BAFTA, and a founding member of the Visual Effects Society and the 5D-Conference. He served on the executive board of the Visual Effects Branch of the Academy in 2016-17.

speaker.title: CEO
speaker.bio:
Wes is the founder and co-owner of Digital Monarch Media Ltd., a company focused on developing and
customizing virtual cinematography tools for film, TV and video games. He has spent the last seven years
working with various film projects in L.A. and London, pushing the boundaries of what can be done in virtual
productions. Among others, he has worked with Steven Spielberg's Ready Player One, Jon Favreau's
The Jungle Book, and most recently has deployed technology on Denis Villeneuve's Blade Runner
2049, and there are many more projects in the works. Prior to the motion-picture industry, Wes studied fine arts, working in oils and charcoal but ultimately incorporating his love for computers into a master's thesis utilizing real-time animation and interaction in traditional media. After university, Wes joined the video game industry as a software developer, focusing on visual effects, physics, and animation, among many other areas that sparked his interest. He was a primary developer for the Need for Speed racing franchise and worked on other products such as James Bond 007: Everything or Nothing, and Plants vs. Zombies Garden Warfare. His career in digital entertainment finally led him to Microsoft Studios and later DMM, where he joined with friends, new and old, to bring these ideas into the foundations that so many creatives are using today.

sessions.title: World, Film, Game: The Transmedia Storytelling of Golf Club: Wasteland

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Golf Club: Wasteland started with the concept of a post-apocalyptic world in ruins that turned into a playground for the ultra-rich. Only after they developed the world did they design the game, story, and music videos – using the same assets and tools within the Unity framework. Closer to a virtual film set with real-time rendering, the experience across multiple media remains cohesive creatively and in terms of the pipelines for different outputs. This talk includes an overview of the development process for the latest music video from the soundtrack, followed by a look at the workflow, directing, camera scripting, and editing. Igor Simic, the creative director, will be joined on stage by Ivan Stankovic, the head programmer.

speaker.bio: Demagog studio was started informally in 2013 by high-school friends, who came together after college. Led by Igor Simić, a graduate of Columbia University, they worked on ﬁlm projects, most notably The Thinker in the Supermarket, Cost-Beneﬁt-Love and Melancholic Drone, which were awarded and screened in ﬁlm festivals and in the contemporary art context. Igor is represented by Galerie Anita Beckers in Frankfurt. A collective exhibition, Virtual Insanity, began August 3, 2018, at Kunsthalle Mainz. In the meantime, Demagog Studio created two video games as art projects, Crisis Expert, an inﬁnite runner on an economic graph, and Children's Play, a game about a factory where children make toys. The development team consists of Ivan Stanković, Miloš Milojević and Miloš Mihajlović. For Golf Club: Wasteland, the team expanded to include the architect and art director Nikola Stepković who created all the art for Golf Club: Wasteland, while Shane Berry, formerly Tokyo-based DJ and now Paris-based musician, is the sound designer and composer of the album. The company was ofﬁcially founded in 2017 with the aim to focus on ﬁlm, video, games and music.

speaker.title: Head Programmer
speaker.bio: Demagog studio was started informally in 2013 by high-school friends, who came together after college. Led by Igor Simić, a graduate of Columbia University, they worked on ﬁlm projects, most notably The Thinker in the Supermarket, Cost-Beneﬁt-Love and Melancholic Drone, which were awarded and screened in ﬁlm festivals and in the contemporary art context. Igor is represented by Galerie Anita Beckers in Frankfurt. A collective exhibition, Virtual Insanity, began August 3, 2018, at Kunsthalle Mainz.
